proof.text: Let  be a second apotome of a medial straight line, and  rational, and to  let there be applied  equal to the square on , producing  as breadth; I say that  is a third apotome.
For let  be the annex to ; therefore ,  are medial straight lines commensurable in square only which contain a medial rectangle. [elem.10.75]

Let  equal to the square on  be applied to , producing  as breadth, and let  equal to the square on  be applied to , producing  as breadth; therefore the whole  is equal to the squares on , ; therefore  is also medial. [elem.10.15 elem.10.23.p.1]
And it is applied to the rational straight line , producing  as breadth; therefore  is rational and incommensurable in length with . [elem.10.22]
Now, since the whole  is equal to the squares on , , and, in these,  is equal to the square on , therefore the remainder  is equal to twice the rectangle , . [elem.2.7]
Let then  be bisected at the point , and let  be drawn parallel to ; therefore each of the rectangles ,  is equal to the rectangle , .
But the rectangle ,  is medial; therefore  is also medial.
And it is applied to the rational straight line , producing  as breadth; therefore  is also rational and incommensurable in length with . [elem.10.22]
And, since ,  are commensurable in square only, therefore  is incommensurable in length with ; therefore the square on  is also incommensurable with the rectangle , . [elem.6.1, elem.10.11]

But the squares on ,  are commensurable with the square on , and twice the rectangle ,  with the rectangle , ; therefore the squares on ,  are incommensurable with twice the rectangle , . [elem.10.13]
But  is equal to the squares on , , and  is equal to twice the rectangle , ; therefore  is also incommensurable with .
But, as  is to , so is  to ; [elem.6.1] therefore  is incommensurable in length with . [elem.10.11]
And both are rational; therefore ,  are rational straight lines commensurable in square only; therefore  is an apotome. [elem.10.73]
I say next that it is also a third apotome.
For, since the square on  is commensurable with the square on , therefore  is also commensurable with , so that  is also commensurable with . [elem.6.1, elem.10.11]

And, since the rectangle ,  is a mean proportional between the squares on , , and  is equal to the square on ,  equal to the square on , and  equal to the rectangle , , therefore  is also a mean proportional between , ; therefore, as  is to , so is  to .

But, as  is to , so is  to , and, as  is to , so is  to ; [elem.6.1] therefore, as  is to , so is  to ; [elem.5.11] therefore the rectangle ,  is equal to [the square on , that is, to] the fourth part of the square on .

Since then ,  are two unequal straight lines, and a parallelogram equal to the fourth part of the square on  and deficient by a square figure has been applied to , and divides it into commensurable parts, therefore the square on  is greater than the square on  by the square on a straight line commensurable with . [elem.10.17]
And neither of the straight lines ,  is commensurable in length with the rational straight line  set out; therefore  is a third apotome. [elem.10.def.3.3]
Therefore etc. Q. E. D.
